p: Recently a systematic review and a meta-analysis of birth cohort studies have shown that increased longitudinal childhood exposure to PM 2.5 and black carbon was associated with increasing risk of subsequent asthma in childhood [ 33]. Also, early childhood exposure to traffic-related air pollution was associated with development of asthma across childhood up to 12Â years of age [ 33]. Increasing exposure to PM 2.5 was associated with sensitization to both aero- and food allergens [ 33].
